intro: Agalinis wrightii, commonly known as Wright's bluemink, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and typically grows in moist, sandy soils in open woodlands and prairies. The plant produces showy, tubular flowers that are usually pink or purple, which attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It has narrow, linear leaves and is often found in disturbed habitats. Agalinis wrightii is an herbaceous perennial that blooms from late spring to early summer.
